text.p: Apple Computer Inc said Friday it introduced two PC-compatible computers that have compatibility with the Windows software standard developed by Microsoft Corp.
The computers -- the Power Macintosh 7300/180 and the Power Macintosh 4400/200 -- are targeted to business and education customers, the company said.

The 166 MHz Intel Pentium processor PCI card, included with the 7300/180 Macintosh, also is available as an upgrade card, allowing PCI-based Power Macintosh computers to run MS-DOS and Windows applications.
The new Power Macintosh systems bundled with PC compatibility cards are scheduled to be available in volume by the end of May and the new PCI card is scheduled to be available in June, Apple said.
Based in Cupertiono, Calif., Apple unveiled the new computer systems at a multimedia technology fair held in Lake Buena Vista, Fla.

"Many of our business and education customers need to be compatible with the Windows operating system, but they will not sacrifice the ease of use and power of the Macintosh," said Phil Schiller, an Apple vice president of marketing.
Both computers will be able to run software written for either an Apple or Windows-compatible systems at the same time.

The Power Macintosh 7300/180 unit will be powered by a speedy MHz PowerPC 604e chip along with the Pentium chip. Apple's Power Macintosh 4400/200 will be powered by a 200 MHz PowerPC 603e processor and a Cyrix Corp PR166 6x86 chip.
The former computer will retial for about $3,200, Apple said. The latter will cost about $2,400. The PC compatibility card will sell for $1,000, the company said.
Apple introduced its first PC-compatible Power Macintosh with an Intel chip one year ago.
